name: Research Synthesis Rubric
description: Evaluates research summaries and synthesis documents for factual accuracy, completeness, logical coherence, and citation quality.

criteria.criterion: Every factual claim is supported by a citation or explicit source
criteria.evidence_required: Quote the unsupported claim and show that no citation follows it
criteria.why: Unsupported claims are the primary failure mode of research synthesis — they turn summaries into opinion pieces

criteria.criterion: Cited sources are internally consistent (no contradictory claims attributed to the same source)
criteria.evidence_required: Show two passages that attribute conflicting claims to the same author or paper
criteria.why: Internal citation contradictions undermine credibility and suggest the source was not actually read

criteria.criterion: Conclusions follow logically from the evidence presented
criteria.evidence_required: Quote the conclusion and show the evidence that fails to support it, or show the logical gap
criteria.why: Non-sequitur conclusions are the most dangerous flaw in research synthesis — they mislead decision-makers

criteria.evidence_required: Show that no limitations section or caveats are present where claims would require them
criteria.why: Overconfident synthesis hides important uncertainty from readers

criteria.criterion: Conflicting findings from different sources are acknowledged and addressed
criteria.evidence_required: Identify a topic where the document presents one view without acknowledging known disagreement in the literature
criteria.why: Cherry-picking evidence invalidates the synthesis and misleads readers

criteria.criterion: The scope and domain of the synthesis is clearly defined
criteria.evidence_required: Show that no clear scope statement or domain definition is present
criteria.why: Without a defined scope, readers cannot judge what the synthesis covers or doesn't cover

criteria.criterion: Key terms are defined consistently throughout the document
criteria.evidence_required: Quote two uses of the same term with different implied meanings
criteria.why: Inconsistent terminology creates confusion and suggests imprecise thinking

criteria.criterion: Quantitative claims include their source and sample context (N, confidence interval, study type)
criteria.evidence_required: Quote a quantitative claim (%, ratio, statistical result) with no source or sample context
criteria.why: Decontextualized numbers are easily misleading — 'studies show 70% improvement' is meaningless without N and methodology

criteria.criterion: The document distinguishes between correlation and causation
criteria.evidence_required: Quote a passage that implies causation from correlational evidence
criteria.why: Correlation/causation conflation is a systematic reasoning error that propagates in synthesis documents

criteria.criterion: Practical implications or recommendations are grounded in the synthesis findings
criteria.evidence_required: Quote a recommendation that is not traceable to a specific finding in the synthesis
criteria.why: Ungrounded recommendations are the synthesis author's opinion, not the literature's conclusion
